Params: Six hours have passed since Hanying met up with Spooner on the outskirts of the port. They have just arrived at the coordinates given by The Cradle.
...How on earth did they manage to build a path on the side of a cliff?
No sign of metals. A complex structure made entirely of wood. Incredible.
Judging from the architectural style, this must have been built before the Golden Age. These wooden structures have remained intact for hundreds of years.
And... I have yet to detect the Punishing Virus in high density.
Even when the Nighter was still traversing the high seas, they still occasionally got attacked by the Corrupted.
In other words, they can no longer imagine a world without the Punishing.
How do they manage to elude the Punishing while being so close to the Kowloong Metropolis?
I've heard that, in addition to the Kowloong Metropolis and the Nighter, Kowloong rules over bigger lands, most of which are devoid of humans.
The path up this mountain is rough and treacherous. Being isolated from the outside world is probably what's been keeping it safe from the virus.
Ha, seems like it's harder to evade humans than the virus.
From a crib by the name of Zero, the Punishing was born.
Since its birth, human blood has always been one of the various colored "blood" that has stained its swaddle blanket.
In the chaos of bloodshed, some have been seeking other colors—while others have been sipping away at the dark, crimson pool as they party like there is no tomorrow.
Before we reached the Nighter, you chose to stop and wait for me just outside the market.
I don't hate humans, but I don't like them either. That's the plain truth.
And I don't want to have anything to do with them.
Spooner shakes his head as he continues up the wooden path deeper into the mountain.
There are no secrets in the Church of Machina.
Most mechanoids have a pristine heart and pure mind.
As Cervantes said, the Church of Machina was built on trust and unity. Members of the Church can confide in one another without reserve.
But even mechanoids have their own past.
By the way, this "Cradle" sure has a peculiar taste.
It just seems odd that a high-tech hacker organization would pick such a remote location to be their base. Feels paradoxical.
It's your first time in Kowloong, I presume?
Correct. I've only heard about this place from others.
This is how it works. For instance, for mechanoids like us, a place like this might be described as "scenic," and that would be an objective truth.
But for the people of Kowloong, lamenting the passing of the seasons amidst the beauty of nature is a habit that's ingrained in their minds.
You mean that humans are often too blinded by their own emotions to see the objective truth of the place?
Unable to understand Hanying's words, Spooner shakes his head.
It is something of a mystery.
But you seem to understand it.
Clear springs cascade over a tapestry of a thousand cliffs.\nWinding trees weaving their greenery through a verdant kingdom vast...
Sorry. It's just a poem I once read somewhere.
I can't think of a fitting way to describe this view off the top of my head, so I recited a line from an ancient Kowloong text.
And I suppose it's supposed to express something very... subtle?
I guess you could say that.
I've only scratched the surface of Kowloong culture, but from what I've seen, Kowloong prefers to use metaphors and euphemisms rather than being direct in their expressions of emotions.
Humans have a habit of concealing their feelings in their words—ironically, though, their feelings are distorted when expressed through language.
That's true, language and words... can introduce much more ambiguity than direct communication among mechanoids.
There is much to lose if humans lose their language and writing.
In Hanying's database in her memory shell, lines that could be used to describe the current scene number in the hundreds.
Even in the same space, at the same time, descriptions of the same entity are, more often than not, different.
And the writer's emotions—their "hearts"—are buried deep within these elusive words.
Is that... the sound of a bell?
Soft chimes of a bell meander through the lush canyons.
According to the civilians who have returned, anyone who sets foot on this mountain will hear this sound.
Plus sightings of other supernatural beings along with lightning and thunder.
Do you believe in those legends?
I... am just not ready to believe in them yet.
Many Kowloong traditions have their roots in humans' reverence for the wonders of nature, along with "legends" that can no longer be verified.
Even the stories you hear get weirder and weirder.
The chimes continue to resonate between the cliffs, but what appears in front of Hanying isn't depicted in any of the Kowloong myths...
